metadata.synopsis: When a creepy older man named Leland Gaunt (Max von Sydow) moves to a small town in Maine and sets up an antique shop, bad things soon follow. Gaunt has the remarkable ability of selling people exactly what they want most, but his ideal purchases come at a price that involves more than just money. Through Gaunt's manipulation, the citizens of the town gradually turn on one another, resulting in violence that Sheriff Alan Pangborn (Ed Harris) struggles to contain.

reviews: This is pulp moviemaking at its worst.
A devilishly fun and mysterious mix of the supernatural and personal stories of drama, crime, and all sorts of small town issues.
One of those far too rare Stephen King movies you can sit through without feeling as if you've been condemned to purgatory for a couple of hours.
By the end of the film, I couldn't have cared less if the town's entire population had been dragged down to Lucifer's fiery abode.
any movie that has the devil laughing to ave maria must be worth something
Overlong, over-produced Stephen King byproduct. Forget it along with Firestarter, In the Mouth of Madness, Maximum Overdrive, and all the others.
Max von Sydow has some good lines, but he delivers them in an utter vacuum.
I needed to get out of this thing long before the insipid finale.
Save your soul for something more important.
One of Stephen King's better film adaptations
A fine adaptation of one of Stephen King's best novels, it almost manages to surpass the book solely on the strength of Von Sydow's glowering villainy.
